choices.text: The thin ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.text: Active transport of Na+ is seen in all of the following cases except in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The thin ascending limb of the loop of Henle is impermeable to water and reabsorbs Na+ passively, driven by concentration gradients. It lacks active Na+ transport mechanisms such as ATP-dependent pumps. In contrast, the proximal tubule, distal convoluted tubule, and collecting duct actively reabsorb Na+ through Na+/K+ ATPase and other transporters.

Explanation of other options:

Collecting duct (Option A): Actively reabsorbs Na+ via ENaC channels regulated by aldosterone.

Distal convoluted tubule (Option B): Uses Na+/Cl- symporters and Na+/K+ ATPase for active Na+ reabsorption.

Proximal tubule (Option D): Reabsorbs ~65% of filtered Na+ via multiple active transporters, including Na+/H+ exchangers and Na+/K+ ATPase.

Key Takeaways:

  • Thin ascending limb = passive Na+ reabsorption only
  • Active Na+ transport occurs in PCT, DCT, collecting duct

choices.text: Distal convoluted tubules in the kidney
Pulmonary epithelial cells in the lungs

questions.text: ENaC channels are found in the following organ systems of the body
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) are present in multiple epithelial tissues, including the distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts of the kidney, where they mediate sodium reabsorption under the influence of aldosterone.
  • They are also found in the pulmonary epithelium, crucial for sodium and fluid transport to maintain alveolar dryness, and in taste buds, where they are involved in salt taste perception.

Explanation of other options:

Distal convoluted tubules in the kidney (Option A): ENaC is essential for fine-tuning Na+ reabsorption here.

Pulmonary epithelial cells in the lungs (Option B): ENaC maintains alveolar fluid balance by transporting sodium.

Taste buds in the tongue (Option C): ENaC plays a role in salt taste transduction.

Key Takeaways:

  • ENaC channels are functionally important in the kidney, lung, and taste buds.
  • They contribute to Na+ balance, fluid clearance, and salt detection.n

choices.text: It refers to the point where glucose 1st appears in urine
Complete reabsorption of glucose regardless of concentration
The relation between plasma glucose and filtered glucose
A gradual increase in glucose excretion as the plasma glucose increases beyond the renal threshold

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the concept of "splay" in glucose excretion in the kidney?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Splay represents the gradual, non-abrupt appearance of glucose in urine as plasma glucose levels exceed the renal threshold (~180 mg/dL).
  • This occurs because not all nephrons have identical transport maximums (Tm) for glucose.
  • As a result, some nephrons begin excreting glucose slightly before others, leading to a curved (splayed) portion on the glucose excretion graph instead of a sharp threshold.

Explanation of other options:

It refers to the point where glucose 1st appears in urine (Option A): Incorrectly defines the renal threshold, not splay.

Complete reabsorption of glucose regardless of concentration (Option B): False reabsorption saturates beyond Tm.

Relation between plasma glucose and filtered glucose (Option C): This is a general property, not specifically describing splay.

Key Takeaways:

  • Splay = gradual glucose appearance in urine post-threshold
  • Occurs due to nephron variability in Tm

choices.text: Glucose is transported by SGLT2 at the apical membrane in the tubules
Transport of D-glucose is greater than L-glucose
Phlorhizin inhibits glucose transport in the kidney

questions.text: The true statement about glucose transport in the kidney is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Glucose reabsorption in the kidney occurs primarily via SGLT2 (sodium-glucose cotransporter 2) at the apical membrane of proximal tubular cells.
  • D-glucose, the physiological isomer, is actively transported, whereas L-glucose is poorly transported.
  • Phlorhizin is a competitive inhibitor of SGLT, blocking glucose reabsorption and increasing its excretion in urine.

Explanation of other options:

Glucose is transported by SGLT 2 at the apical membrane in the tubules (Option A): Correct; SGLT2 handles the majority (~90%) of glucose reabsorption.

Transport of D-glucose is greater than L-glucose (Option B): Correct; only D-glucose is efficiently reabsorbed.

Phlorhizin inhibits the glucose transport in the kidney (Option C): Correct; blocks SGLT, mimicking glucosuria.

Hence, the correct answer is All of the above(Option D)

Key Takeaways:

  • SGLT2 mediates glucose uptake in the proximal tubule
  • Phlorhizin inhibits glucose reabsorption
  • Only D-glucose is efficiently transported

questions.text: A 51-year-old man with poorly controlled hypertension is found to have mildly elevated serum creatinine and BUN levels. His glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is reduced. Despite this, his serum sodium remains within the normal range, and there are no signs of fluid retention. Which physiological mechanism is primarily responsible for maintaining normal serum sodium levels in this setting?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Glomerulotubular balance is the intrinsic ability of the nephron to reabsorb a constant fraction of filtered sodium and water, even when GFR is reduced.
  • This mechanism helps maintain sodium homeostasis despite variations in GFR, which explains why the patient's serum sodium remains normal despite a low GFR and elevated creatinine and BUN.

Explanation of other options:

Altered aldosterone concentration (Option A): Regulates sodium handling, but serum sodium is typically altered when aldosterone is abnormal, which is not the primary mechanism here.

Efferent arteriolar constriction (Option B): Maintains GFR, but doesn't directly stabilize serum sodium.

Increased sodium reabsorption from DCT (Option D): Affects fine-tuning, but glomerulotubular balance is the main compensatory response to decreased GFR.

Key Takeaways:

  • Glomerulotubular balance maintains sodium reabsorption proportional to GFR
  • Keeps serum sodium normal in early renal dysfunction
  • A proximal tubule-based autoregulatory mechanism

questions.text: Which among the following is/are the disease related to the transport of substances in the kidney occurring due to a genetic mutation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All listed conditions are genetic tubulopathies caused by mutations affecting renal tubular transport proteins.


Dent disease (Option A): X-linked; affects proximal tubule handling of proteins and ions. Liddle syndrome (Option B): Pseudoaldosteronism due to ENaC hyperactivity → hypertension with low renin and aldosterone.

Bartter syndrome (Option C): Impaired Na+/K+/2Cl- reabsorption, mimicking chronic loop diuretic use.

choices.text: Ascending limb of Loop of Henle

questions.text: The aquaporin I channels for water transport are found in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Aquaporin-1 (AQP1) is highly expressed in the proximal tubule and descending limb of the loop of Henle, where it facilitates constitutive (always open) water reabsorption.
  • It is not regulated by ADH, unlike AQP2 in the collecting ducts.

Explanation of other options:

Collecting ducts (Option A): Express AQP2, which is ADH-regulated, not AQP1.

Ascending limb of Loop of Henle (Option B): Impermeable to water, contains no aquaporins.

Skin (Option D): Aquaporins are present in some skin layers (e.g., AQP3), but AQP1 is not dominant here.

Key Takeaways:

  • AQP1 = water transport in proximal tubule and descending limb
  • Not ADH-dependent
  • Collecting ducts use AQP2, ascending limb is water-impermeable

choices.text: The descending limb of the loop of Henle
Capillaries around the juxtra-medullary nephron tubules
The ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.text: In the kidney, the countercurrent exchanger mechanism occurs at the level of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A countercurrent exchanger refers to the passive exchange of solutes and water between the vasa recta (capillaries) and the interstitium of the renal medulla, which preserves the medullary concentration gradient established by the loop of Henle.

This occurs primarily around juxtamedullary nephrons, whose long loops and accompanying capillaries penetrate deep into the medulla, allowing efficient exchange without washing away solutes.

Explanation of other options:

The descending limb of the loop of Henle (Option A): Involved in countercurrent multiplication, not an exchanger; permeable to water, helps concentrate tubular fluid.

Proximal tubule (Option C): Major site of solute and water reabsorption, but not part of countercurrent mechanisms.

The ascending limb of the loop of Henle (Option D): Part of countercurrent multiplication, actively transports solutes but is impermeable to water.

Key Takeaways:

A countercurrent exchanger occurs in the vasa recta

It helps maintain the medullary gradient

Distinct from countercurrent multiplication

choices.text: Passive transport of sodium ions from the ascending thin segment into the interstitium
Active transport of sodium from the inner medullary collecting duct
Diffusion of urea from the collecting duct into the medullary interstitium

questions.text: The single effect in counter counter-current multiplier mechanism occurs due to
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The single effect in the countercurrent multiplier mechanism refers to the creation of a concentration gradient by the active transport of Na+ and Cl- from the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle into the interstitium, making the interstitial fluid hyperosmotic relative to the tubular fluid.
  • The ascending limb is impermeable to water, while the descending limb is permeable, enabling the gradient that drives the multiplier system.
  • Therefore, active transport of sodium, not passive diffusion or urea transport, underlies the single effect.

Explanation of other options:

Passive transport of sodium ions from ascending thin segments into the interstitium (Option A): Incorrect, as active, not passive transport in the thick ascending limb is key.

Active transport of sodium from inner medullary collecting duct (Option B): Not involved in the single effect; plays a role in urine concentration but not the initial gradient.

Diffusion of urea from the collecting duct into medullary interstitium (Option C): Important for urea recycling, not the single effect.

questions.text: Which tissues or cell types do not express the UT-B isoform of the urea transporter?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • UT-B is a type of urea transporter protein primarily expressed in erythrocytes and the descending limb of the vasa recta.
  • It facilitates urea transport across cell membranes, especially in areas involved in urea recycling for maintaining the medullary osmotic gradient.
  • In contrast, collecting ducts express UT-A isoforms (especially UT-A1 and UT-A3), not UT-B. Hence, UT-B is not found in the collecting duct.

Urea transporter (UT) in the Kidney:

  1. UT-A1: Apical membrane of IMCD (Inner medullary collecting duct)
  2. UT-A2: Descending thin loop of Henle
  3. UT-A3: Basolateral membrane of IMCD
  4. UT-B: Descending vasa recta

choices.text: Descending limb of the loop of Henle
Ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.text: In which segment of the tubules in the nephron is the fluid typically hypotonic?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tubular fluid becomes hypotonic as it reaches the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) due to the active reabsorption of Na+, Cl- in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, which is impermeable to water. This solute reabsorption without accompanying water retention dilutes the tubular fluid, making it hypotonic before it enters the DCT.

Explanation of other options:

Proximal convoluted tubule (Option A): Isosmotic reabsorption of solutes and water; fluid remains isotonic.

Descending limb of loop of Henle (Option B): Permeable to water but not solutes; fluid becomes hypertonic.
Ascending limb of loop of Henle (Option C): Site of solute reabsorption without water; fluid becomes hypotonic after this segment, not within it.

Key Takeaways:

Hypotonic fluid reaches DCT; due to solute reabsorption in the ascending limb, a key step in urine concentration.

choices.text: Free water clearance is zero means the kidney is not able to excrete excess water.
Free water clearance is positive, showing efficient kidneys to excrete excess water.
Free water clearance is negative, indicating a net reabsorption of water

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male with chronic kidney disease visited the physician for regular follow-up. The doctor found swelling in the legs. On laboratory investigation urine osmolality of 80 mOsm/kg and the plasma osmolality of 300 mOsm/kg. Urine output is 3 liters/day.
Which statement from the list below is true about free water clearance?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Free water clearance (CH2O) is positive when urine is hypotonic (urine osmolality < plasma osmolality), meaning the kidneys are excreting excess free water. In this case, urine osmolality is 80 mOsm/kg vs. plasma osmolality of 300 mOsm/kg, indicating dilute urine. Hence, CH2O is positive, showing the kidneys are attempting to rid the body of water even though chronic kidney disease may impair overall function.

  1. positive CH2O = dilute urine;
  2. negative CH2O = concentrated urine; urine < plasma osmolality
  3. Free water clearance is zero means the kidney is not able to excrete excess water

Explanation of other options:

(Option A): Incorrect zero CH2O means urine osmolality equals plasma; not necessarily impaired excretion.

Free water clearance is negative, indicating a net reabsorption of water (Option C): Incorrect in this contexturine is dilute, not concentrated.

questions.text: Which of the following substances, when administered in large quantities, does (es) not inhibit vasopressin (ADH) secretion, but still produce osmotic diuresis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that increases the osmolality of plasma and renal tubular fluid, leading to diuresis without suppressing vasopressin (ADH) secretion.

Unlike substances like ethanol and water, mannitol does not impact the central regulation of ADH but induces water loss by its presence in the filtrate.

Explanation of other options:

Ethanol (Option B): Inhibits vasopressin secretion at the level of the hypothalamus, leading to diuresis.

Water (Option C): Large quantities dilute plasma osmolality, inhibiting vasopressin release via hypothalamic osmoreceptors.

Key Takeaways:

Mannitol causes osmotic diuresis without affecting ADH secretion

Ethanol and water suppress ADH

questions.text: A 57-year-old male has a history of hypertension and progression towards heart failure. His plasma K+ level is 2.9 meq/L. Which of the following diuretics is helpful in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and aldosterone antagonist, making it ideal for patients with hypokalemia (K+ = 2.9 mEq/L) and heart failure. It counteracts the potassium-wasting effects of other diuretics, and its mortality benefit in heart failure further supports its use.

Explanation of other options:

Acetazolamide (Option A): A carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, causes bicarbonate and potassium loss, worsening hypokalemia.

Furosemide (Option B): A loop diuretic, strongly wastes potassium contraindicated in existing hypokalemia.

Metolazone (Option D): A thiazide-like diuretic, also increases potassium excretion, suitable in hypokalemia.

Key Takeaways:

Spironolactone is preferred in hypokalemia and heart failure; Loop and thiazide diuretics exacerbate hypokalemia; Monitor K+ levels in all diuretic therapies.

choices.text: The first urge to void urine

questions.text: Which of the following events coincides with the one marked with an arrow?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The arrow in the graph marks a point at which intravascular volume reaches ~150 mL, causing a slight rise in intravascular pressure.
  • This corresponds with the first urge to void, which typically occurs between 150-200 mL as stretch receptors in the bladder wall are stimulated.
  • Though the bladder can accommodate more, this is the threshold for initial conscious awareness of bladder filling.

Explanation of other options:

Sensation of fullness (Option A): Occurs later, at higher volumes (~300 mL).

Voiding of urine (Option C): Happens when volume reaches ~400-500 mL with a sharp rise in pressure.

choices.text: Damage to the sympathetic supply to the bladder

questions.text: A 37-year-old male visited the physician due to complaints of reduced desire for urination, and once it commenced, it was difficult to stop micturition. The doctor investigated the patient and did all neurological investigations. Where is the lesion located?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The superior frontal gyrus is part of the cerebral cortex involved in voluntary control of micturition, including initiation and inhibition.
  • Lesions here can impair conscious control, leading to difficulty initiating or stopping urination and reduced awareness of bladder filling, consistent with the patient's symptoms.
  • This area communicates with the pontine micturition center and sacral spinal cord to regulate bladder function.

Explanation of other options:

Inhibitory area in the midbrain (Option A): No specific "inhibitory area" known; primary control is cortical and pontine.

Damage to sympathetic supply to bladder (Option C): Affects bladder filling, but not typically associated with difficulty stopping urination or reduced urge.

Key Takeaways:

  • Superior frontal gyrus controls voluntary micturition.
  • Lesion causes impaired initiation/stopping of urination
  • Cortical bladder control is essential for continence
